pr_title: Fix two instances of same replica during replica addition

timeline.message:
WIP: Fix two instances of same replica during replica addition

When adding a new replica to certain node, the node first creates a
bootstrap replica and uses it to perform boostrap work(i.e. allocate
files and create new store). Afterwards, the node updates Helix
InstanceConfig which notifies all listeners in cluster (including itself).
When dealing with InstanceConfig change, this node creates a second
instance of same replica and adds it into in-mem clustermap.
The consequence is storage manager holds a different instance from Helix
Cluster Manager, which mistakenly adds self replica into peer replicas
when performing replication catchup. It blocks decommission process
because there is always a self replica that will never catch up.
This PR fixes this problem by maintaining boostrap replica set in
cluster manager and it checks if there are existing replica instances when
hanlding InstanceConfig change.
fix test failure and add unit tests

timeline.bodyText: Would it be worth having a metric for this event? Would this mean that the replica never gets added until the machine is restarted or will it get added eventually?
timeline.author: cgtz

replies.bodyText:
Actually, replica == null should not happen in practice. If everything goes well, then the replica should be present in bootstrap replica map. If failure occurs during bootstrap, there are two cases to discuss:
(1)  new replica is added but node crashes before updating Helix InstanceConfig
There is no InstanceConfig change. When machine is restarted, node will re-do replica addition and newly added replica should be in the map.
(2) InstanceConfig is updated and then node crashes immediately
Since new replica is already in InstanceConfig, once machine is restarted the new replica will be added to in-mem clustermap when handling initial InstanceConfig change (a different code path within createNewInstance() method)
There is only one rare case (human error) where we mistakenly update InstanceConfig of existing node by adding new replica rather than update IdealState, which may trigger this replica == null statement. In this case, it won't be added. Instead of a metric, I think I should throw an exception here and change the warn to error.

timeline.bodyText: Instead of passing the map directly to DynamicClusterChangeHandler, could you add a AmbryReplica popBootstrapReplica(String partition) method to ClusterChangeHandlerCallback?
timeline.author: cgtz

replies.bodyText: Yeah, we can do that. Actually, it is quite safe in terms of concurrency. There should be only one dc (where the current node sits) calling this method.

Considering the context of this method, I think I will rename it to fetchBootstrapReplica. It fetches a replica out (if any) from bootstrap replica map and add it into in-memory clustermap.
(Just like fetchRequest() in GetBlobOperation, DeleteOperation, etc)
